Sometimes it can be a little buggy, but honestly, that's part of the fun, and the bugs don't break the game by any means. And even if you don't get very good, the real reward comes from the awkward, flailing movements that still, after 60+ hours of play, occasionally make me laugh helplessly.

What I've learned is that this game has two crowds. One crowd, who picks the game up for an hour or two (or less), and decides it's kinda okay, but too simplistic for their sophisticated tastes, and who still laughs at d!ck jokes anyway? And then there's the other crowd who gives it a chance, really learns how to use the mechanics, has a total blast and falls in love.

Now, there are obnoxious jerks who play online, that think they're funny, and waste your time slapping your tender bits until the timer ticks all the way down. But just use that as motivation to get good at the game so you can beat all those jerks, and eventually they'll go away, because chances are, they're part of Crowd #1. And anybody you like playing with, look up on Steam and add them, and after a bit, you won't run out of people to play with.

I give this game 10/10 hellicoptering dongles.

reviewText:
The main casualty of advancements in online gaming has been local co-op. We all have memories of convening at a friend’s basement or room and playing games together while screaming about screen-peeking, cheat codes, and all other manner of sore loser-isms. Developer Stegersaurus Software Inc. shares those memories and made Mount Your Friends as a callback to the glory days of old. Needless to say, Mount Your Friends is definitely a much more explicit game than anything we played growing up. Never in my life did I expect to write this sentence but the dong physics are second to none.

The first thing you notice about Mount Your Friends is the gang of Speedo-clad, Diglett-looking bodybuilders that you control. The premise of the original mode of the game is simple enough: each player has 60 seconds to climb on top of an ever-growing pile of the other players and get as high as they possibly can, with whoever tops the pile being the winner.

The challenge comes from the control scheme. Like the Assassin’s Creed franchise, each of the four input buttons controls one limb. Hold down a button and move the joystick to swing a limb; once you release the input button, if you are touching a surface, that limb will adhere to that surface and won’t let go until you manually move the limb again.

Climbing the tower of muscular flesh can be easier once you figure out how to fling yourself from limb ledge to limb ledge, but until then you’ll find yourself slowly climbing up with all the grace of a newborn giraffe. However, this method runs the risk of either under- or overshooting your target and finding yourself flopping through the air until you splat onto the ground. While playing this game with friends, you find yourself either cackling like a madman at their ineptitude or malevolently planning on how to smack the controller out of their hands while playing it off as an accident.

In addition to the original race-to-the-top mode, there are a myriad of gameplay modes for both single and multiplayer. You can race to see who can traverse a rocky obstacle course and collect the most coins, make a bridge across a chasm, or even a freestyle mode without a timer to see what flexing muscular shapes you can build.

The music in the game is just as well-designed as every other aspect of the game. While playing a head-to-head game, the music takes on this epic feel, as if climbing this mountain of digital flesh is as grand as traversing Middle-Earth. I half-expected Gandalf to pop up as the next climber I controlled. If you pull off a particularly long climb, you hear your character stretch and strain to get that last bit of height.

As a multiplayer game, Mount Your Friends is as hilarious and entertaining as they come. Unfortunately, the single player mode gets old after a while. It’s not that the game is boring, but without playing against someone to challenge you, the game loses its appeal. Luckily for those without friends nearby, Mount Your Friends is playable online as well as with a local competitive co-op. There are global leaderboards for those who want to push themselves to keep climbing, but most of the fun comes from watching your friends struggle to climb above the human obstacle you put above them.

reviewText:
There isn't much to Mount your Friends. It's a quirky competitive game where you use physics and sticky hands and feet to climb and fling yourself to the top of the tower made up of all the other players. Every player mounting the tower makes it taller until eventually someone wins. It's really simple, well polished, but really fun to play with friends.

Solo content is available but it's not too interesting and without enemy AI, it's mostly challenges such as climb one of several given obstacle courses. Multiplayer is the preferred choice if you can grab some friends to play with. You'll be hard pressed at times to find anyone else hosting a public game. Customization is also an option, you can use some of the preset stuff to customize your team or import your own images for the body and head. This is a really cool feature that me and my friends have been abusing to import ridiculous looking characters into our game. The downside is they don't work in multiplayer, only you can see them unless you share the exact same picture with everyone else you're playing with. I'm hoping the devs patch something in to fix this but until then, the best solution is packing everything all your friends are using into a zip file on dropbox and just pass it around to all your friends.

Multiplayer has 2 Gameplay modes and 2 Variable Weather Effects that change the gameplay. Vertical climb is a simple climb to the top of the growing tower of friends. Horizontal is the same but the tower must extend to the right of the screen instead of the top. These two games modes are accompanied by Space and Storm weather effects which change the physics somewhat to challenge you. Space gives you low gravity, which makes jumping and flinging yourself around easier, but also more dangerous. Flinging yourself too far on Horizontal can lead to falling into the pit below and instantly losing, while in Vertical, you can accidentally fling yourself off the tower which spells doom for most situation. Storm halts your progress by always pushing you to the left in a windy storm. This makes it hard for everyone to move or climb and flinging yourself is a lot harder.

Overall it's quick and easy fun, you can kill time playing it or have a game night with friends, flinging off of Bill Nye in a Bra to achieve your victory. While the Single player content is lacklustre, Multiplayer is fun and worth the money if you have friends to play it with.

At £4 it's an easy purchase, unless you really need that £3.99 Whopper Meal.

reviewText:
This game succeeds in so many ways it deserves to be declared a MASTERPIECE.

First of all, you'll find how a very simple idea is fully developed and leads to complex but extremely fun gameplay. It's ideal for both the casual player who is looking for some laughing fun and the expert who wants to compete beating scores on the leaderboards.

It offers several game modes for both single player and multiplayer (online and local coop) where you face very different challenges (highest climb, longest run, collect coins, etc.) by controlling the sticky body.

The aesthetics are remarkable but the heads and bodies are customizable and there is even a 'safe for work' mode in case you find the original skins a bit too spicy ;)

Play multiplayer to split your sides, learn some techniques and make a fool of yourself; or play single player to practice or compete on the leaderboards. As it's physics based, there is always room for improvement, you never master it completely.

This is one of those games for a lifetime (and it's only $5 !!).

reviewText:
Surprisingly good for 5 dollars.

What really makes this game is the control scheme: unlike Super Meat Boy, when this game's loading screen says it's best to play with a controller, I actually disagree. Super Meat Boy was a platformer, where a controller really was an upgrade... but here? Here, I sort of think it works pretty well to use keyboard and mouse.

The controls are 80% of the game. The rest is learning the physics and planning where to put each figure.

Mastering the controls is the real game here. And it's a challenge, but for the right reasons. It's strangely fun, at least for me.

And you can pick a safe-for-work mode if staring at mostly naked men climbing each other somehow isn't for you.

Ultimately, this is another of my recommended 'minute' games, where you can play and get something out of it in the few minutes between having to do the next chore or bit of homework. Not a complex game, but the simple challenge of the controls and climbing physics is enjoyable, and there's more to this game than the silly title and nearly-naked characters would lead you to believe.
